fields.summary: forward email should allow group
Hide individual field values
Automatically add existing open issues to newly defined versions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7266].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 20 June 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

In the spirit of transparency, we are going to close this feature request *for JIRA Cloud*. It's been 18 months since we last provided an update and we do not have any plans to introduce support for custom email templates in JIRA Core or JIRA Software. (This is how we've been interpreting this feature request, as editing velocity templates has never been possible for JIRA Cloud). If you are a JIRA Server customer, please continue watching JRASERVER-7266 for updates.

*[JIRA Service Desk|https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/service-desk] supports customizable email notifications for requests* with HTML, CSS, and plaintext templates and custom variables. [You can learn more about configuring custom notifications in the JIRA Service Desk in the JIRA Service Desk Cloud documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskcloud/managing-service-desk-notifications-732528936.html#Managingservicedesknotifications-StylenotificationswithHTML,CSS,andplaintexttemplates].

For some cases where you want special email notifications for certain events  (like the one mentioned in the comment immediate before this one), the most straightforward workaround may be to use a service like Zapier or IFTTT to receive webhooks from JIRA Cloud and send an email customized to your needs.

We are committed to improving the notifications experience in JIRA Cloud over time. Our priority is to focus first on sending the right amount of notifications at the right time (JRACLOUD-1369) and then we can consider adding additional customization options in the future.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
JIRA Product Management
{panel}

*Original request description:*
 
As a JIRA administrator I want to make sure that the notifications sent from JIRA are actionable and reflect the recipients' expectation related to the content and format. I can change current JIRA email format by manual editing of velocity files, but that is not an efficient way of doing so, and it is not supported for Cloud instances of JIRA.
 
What I need is an email template editor in JIRA's web-interface so that users can create customised email templates that are used for notifications and subscriptions.
It would also be ideal to have the ability to create and manage multiple email templates which could be then assigned to the relevant filter subscription or notification.
fields.summary: Create an Email Template Editor in the UI to Replace Editing Velocity Templates

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa} *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7261]. {panel} It's been reported that when that mis-configured Svn plugin properties file (or removal of the specified user account) can stop Jira from starting. We should invesigate this and perhaps try to contain the error (to not be so catastrophic) From e-mail: Problem Description: I have a properly configured and running Jira server, with the Subversion plugin indexing and working against a Subversion repository. I was using a local .htaccess file to authenticate users, with usernames and passwords added in manually, for the Subversion repository. In the .htaccess file I had a 'jira' user, which was configured in the subversion plugin properties file to connect to the subversion server. This morning I switched authentication for our Subversion repo to an enterprise LDAP server. It works fine for all users - but the 'jira' user that the svn plugin in Jira was configured to use did not exist in the LDAP directory. I restarted Jira (for other reasons) and it failed to come back up. The relevant parts of catalina.out (I believe) are copied below. I have resolved the issue by removing the svn plugin from my running Jira installation, and will either add a jira account to my LDAP directory, or connect via a different method to the Svn repository. However, I thought you guys would like to know that a mis-configured Svn plugin properties file (or removal of the specified user account) can stop Jira from starting... fields.summary: Mis-configured Subversion plugin will cause JIRA to fail to startup

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7257].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 13 Jan 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days; however there are no immediate plans to put this suggestion on our near term roadmap.

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Daniel Franz
dfranz@atlassian.com
Principal Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}
  

We need the ability to select multiple values in a cascading list. 

It would be good to also have an ALL option under each section for quickly selecting all options in a branch.
fields.summary: Allow multiple values to be selected in a cascading list
Find Issues filter does not look at Estimate Fields
Counter-intuitive access to Developer Workload Report

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7211].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 22 April 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with JIRA.

At this time, this suggestion is not on the JIRA development roadmap. Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
[dmeyer@atlassian.com|mailto:dmeyer@atlassian.com]
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

It looks like the feature to display an issue key in strikethrough depends on the issue having been resolved.
This improvement request is to
* add a system parameter:
** Show Keys as strike-through: (x) Never, (/) If Resolved (i.e. Resolution not empty) (x) Based on Status
* add a new field to the Status screen (show issues in this status as strikethrough) that is enabled if the system parameter "Based on Status" is selected.

For example, the end result of a development ticket is status "Closed" - even though "Resolved" has a resolution set, it isn't considered done yet until verified by QA. The end result of a support ticket is "Answered". So, in the status maintenance screen, the statuses "Answered" and "Closed" would be flagged to show the issue in strikethrough font.

This enables people who hate the feature entirely the ability to turn it off; it enables people who like the current functionality to leave it as is, and it allows people to control when the issue is displayed as strikethrough based on status.

{quote}
Original issue description: show strike through for closed, rather than resolved issues.  Our users are confusing struckthrough issues as closed, and I was wondering if it would be possible to make this feature work only once an issue has been closed, not resolved. Because resolved means it hasn't been tested yet. From an implementation point of view, obviously this would have to be configurable to support current usage.
{quote}
fields.summary: Allow configuration of when issue keys are shown in strike-through font

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7208].
  {panel}

i have found it useful to have a printout of a report that displays all outstanding issues in a table format.  JIRA currently (version 3.2.2) includes _some_ of the data associated with an issue, but does not display an issue's comments.  What i envision is adding another column to the "Issue Navigator".  This column contains all of the comments of this current issue.  (The description would also be displayed.)

yes, this might very well generate a very long (and potentially wide) report.  the value in such a report is that the printout can be taken to a meeting and an intelligent discussion about all issues can be had.  currently, the printout does not provide the comments, so unless everyone in the meeting room has access to a computer, it is not easy to discuss the details of the issues.

potential solutions would include the possibility of displaying the results of a filter via a choice of views.

this is similar to this issue: http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-564  what is different is that i am looking for a tabular layout (to shorten the print out) instead of a listing as detailed in the issue body.

-markus
fields.summary: printout summary table displaying all comments
Soap: addComponent()

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7201].
  {panel}

go to http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/

log out if automatic login is active

return to the home page
use the quick search box on the home page 
type in a 3-4 digit number (possible issue key) for example '567'

you get a single result : 

http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/567
which is an error page
the URL is built without a project key 

This doesn't occur as soon as you click on 'browse project' in the navigation bar (then, a default current project seems to be defined and used in building the URL)

Limitation of the quick search on issue keys not going accross projects ??
fields.summary: Quick search for a number should search across multiple projects
lower case issue keys not displaying as link in issue (description, comments, etc.)
The sub-tasks link to parent issue is created by a web action after the Issue Created event has been fired
SLA tracking for each issue type
Make Resolution field optional

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7150].
  {panel}

When I try to create a subtask, the first screen that I am presented with reads:

"Step 1 of 2: Choose the issue type...
  Issue Type: Sub-task"

The form only has 1 select box for the Issue Type, and the only possible value in the box is "Sub-task".  Why would you ever even present this screen?  There is nothing to do.
fields.summary: Unnecessary screen when creating a subtask
Issue List does not differentiate issue types

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7133].
  {panel}

When I do a time tracking report, it would be great if the issues were directly editable in that issue navigator view.

i.e.

key | status | priority| summary   |  original estimate | estimated time remaining | Time Spent | Accuracy
a-12 open   3             blah               2d                              2d*                                             unknown*     unknown
a-13 open   3             blah               2d                              2d*                                             unknown*     unknown

We would like to directly edit the fields with a *, without having to select each issue, then edit the issue, then log work done, then type in the amount of work done an select the "set remaining time".  It's too cumbersome.

Better workflow: have the fields be directly editable.  

We do this every day, and it's very very painful.  If I had the choice to use something different, I would -> that's how painful it is.
fields.summary: Allow issue editing in the issue navigator
Add methods of health montioring for JIRA service
Ensure JIRA respects conditions on the Create Issue initial workflow transition.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7108].

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 4 January 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days; unfortunately we don't have any plans to support this in JIRA for the foreseeable future.

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].
 
I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.
 
Regards,
Dave Meyer
dmeyer@atlassian.com
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

In jira-application.properties I see the availability to customize the email header format. This is what I have:

# Specifies the From: header format in notification emails. Default is of the form "John Doe (JIRA) <jira@company.com>".
# Available variables are ${fullname}, ${email} and ${email.hostname}
# If commented out, format is just 'jira@company.com'
# default: jira.email.fromheader.format = ${fullname} (JIRA)
jira.email.fromheader.format = ${email} (${fullname}) via JIRA

The problem is that the actual address (if the user clicks to "Reply") is not that, but the one specified for the project, so users will just click Reply not realizing that the reply to address is not what is shown. What's more, I do not see any of the variables available to show the sender's address (e.g. project1@company.com). Is there a way to get the reply-to address to be the actual user's address (it SHOWS in the email as the sender). Do you understand my question?

Thanks
fields.summary: Option to set sender address reply to actual user's address in email notifications
Sort users by lastname, firstname

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7056].

{panel:title=22nd December 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi all,

Thanks for participating in this issue, either by voting, commented or just watching. We highly value your feedback in all forms, and through suggestions in jira.atlassian.com is not different. We use this channel often to learn the best we can with how customers use JIRA and how we can continue to improve the experience for as many users as possible.

We have revisited this issue again recently and wanted to reiterate that there are still currently no plans to implement this suggestion, and it is not currently on any JIRA team’s roadmap at this stage.

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.


Regards,
Kerrod Williams
Kerrod (dot) Williams (at) atlassian (dot) com
Product Manager, JIRA

{panel}

We have a workflow that requires issues to be linked on a regular basis to their parent issues.  Thus we have Parent Issue P-1 and then we create user stories U-1, U-2, ..., U-n to support it, where n may be a large number.  Currently, we need to create the issue and then manually click Link Issue then find the right one, then click 'Accept' etc etc.

Can I propose a new 'Create Linked Issue' as part of an issue's operations?  You would then see the same screen as 'Create New Issue' but you'd also have a link drop-down to select the link you want.  When the issue is created the link is then there already.

I think this would greatly simplify the workflow of creating issue links.  Thanks!
fields.summary: Improvement to issue link creation
Concurrency problem when running Workflow Current Step Check
Make log parsing case insensitve on JIRA project key

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7020].
{panel}
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 26 May 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks so much for your votes and comments on this feature request.

We are in the early stages of a sustained investment in simplifying project configuration and making it easier for individual project owners to maintain their projects. Our goal is to help teams get JIRA projects that are tuned to meet their needs, make it easy for anyone to set up a JIRA project, and reduce the amount of repetitive configuration work that JIRA administrators need to do.

At the same time, we are committed to maintaining the power and controls that JIRA provides to administrators to achieve standardization across projects and shared configurations.

We see templates as the most viable solution for delivering this capability; however it's critical that we build templates as part of the larger system of setting up and maintaing projects, and we need to ensure this system can also meet our goals around making JIRA project configuration simple and accessible for everyone.

So while we do expect to provide templates at some point in the future, it's part of a much larger set of improvements that will span a significant period of time. Thanks for your patience while we work to make JIRA better. We will update this issue as we have more information.

If you're looking for an immediate solution, there are a number of add-ons in the Atlassian Marketplace for JIRA Server:
 * [Configuration Manager for JIRA|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.botronsoft.jira.configurationmanager]
 * [Project Creator for JIRA|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.wittified.jira.project-creator]
 * [Gaia for JIRA|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/ca.nuum.gaia]
 * [Project Configurator|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.awnaba.projectconfigurator.projectconfigurator]

Unfortunately I am not aware of any add-ons for JIRA Cloud to support this, but I will update this issue if one becomes available.

Cheers,

Dave
JIRA Product Management
dmeyer@atlassian.com
{panel}
*Original request description:*

This will allow admins to have a project template that can be copied each time a new project is selected. This will save the admins time from associating new projects with schemes after creation.

One way to implement this would be to create 'project schemes’.
fields.summary: Allow support for project schemes or templates
Ability to edit category of a project through SOAP

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-7008].
  {panel}

When adding a comment to an issue, the comment can be set to be Viewable By a specific group. The groups that are listed in this select box are the groups that the user is assigned to.

My suggestion: This list should instead include the groups AND the users that has the Browse Projects permission for the specfic project and NOT the groups that the current isuer is assigned to.

Today, i can make comments viewable to groups that don't have browse permission to the project. That does not give much sense.

Further more: it would be great, if the box was a multiple select box.
fields.summary: Comment Viewable By should show groups with project browse permission

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6985].

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 13 Jan 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days.

We are assessing how we can simplify and improve the filter sharing model. This suggestion is important for the JIRA development team, but we have not scheduled work and cannot provide an estimate.

I understand this may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Daniel Franz
dfranz@atlassian.com
Principal Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

Currently the filter-sharing is something we use a lot. And it works really well.
However, the problem with sharing the filters is that only one person can modify them - and that they can only be shared with one group.
Ultimately, the filters are owned by a user.

What would be nice is if you could save filters at the Project Level - and anyone who is a project administrator can Manage them.
They would be public by nature - ie if you can browse the project, you can see the filters.
I guess they would also be for that project only...
fields.summary: Project-level Filters
Add service to get all custom fields for a project and issue type

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6982].
  {panel}

This would be just like getSavedFilters, except it returns the default filters:

 - All
- Outstanding
- Unscheduled
- Assigned to me
- Reported by me
	- Resolved recently
- Added recently
- Updated recently
- Most important

This would be quite useful!  I would really like this feature.
fields.summary: SOAP: getPresetFilters()
SOAP: createFilter(forProjectKey)
Allow users to add the default dashboard page to their dashboard.
Rename sub-tasks to sub-issues

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6922].
  {panel}

When tracking issues from multiple third-parties, it would be very helpful if JIRA could track which third-party each user belonged to. With this information there is a lot that could be done:
 - provide security so that third-party users have more privileges on issues from their own company
 - extend the search interface so that users can simply search all of their own issues
 - similarly these users can now create useful filters such as 'my company's open issue'

Ideally this company/third-party information would be collected in a secure way so that it can be relied upon.
 - require the user provide an email from the company's domain, and then verify it
 - require an administrative user from each company so that they can add and remove users

I realize that some of this could be done as custom fields and workflows, but it would make sense to me for this to be a core part of the product. For example, on jira.atlassian.com, I'd love to be able to write filters such as "my company's unresolved issues". I also would really like to be able to edit issues created by my co-workers, and to remove ex-employees or reassign their issues to someone else.
fields.summary: Add support for tracking third parties
The releasenotes does not contain the date a version was released
Display a warning when removing a user from the 'jira-users' group

 Revision 1.1.1.1 has no main branch - ignoring revision.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 4 January 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days.

Simplifying project setup, configuration, and maintenance is one of the JIRA team's top priorities right now. We are in the early stages of a big investment in making it easier to get started with a JIRA project and maintain a large number of projects at scale.

We expect that our work will eventually incorporate additional flexibility for configuring field behavior on a per-project basis, but we can't make any commitments on exactly what we will support or when this will be released.

We will continue to update this issue as we release new capabilities for project administration. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or feedback.

It's important to understand that we rarely try to implement individual features from jira.atlassian.com, but instead take a holistic look at the problem and use feedback from the comments here and a [dozen other sources|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com] of customer input to solve the core problems.

Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or feedback.
 
Regards,
Dave Meyer
dmeyer@atlassian.com
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

In the custom field configuration context, it is not possible to  choose a project if it has already been associated to another configuration context of the same custom field. For instance, it is not possible to make the following associations:

Task, project1, configuration context 1
Task, project2, configuration context 2
Bug, project1, configuration context 3
Bug, project2, configuration context 4
fields.summary: Allow more than one custom field context to be associated with the same project but different issue types

fields.description:
Actually (when creating an issue) component / version selector is a multi-select list. 

This is not optimal. 

1) user can click "accidentally" on an unwated item (thus, changing his selection)
2) when the list of possible items contains 10 - 15 items and when item #1, #6 and #10 are choosen, user has to scroll the list to *find* selected items

So, such selectors should be of (what i call) type "shuttle" (see attached sketch)

Would be great if atlassian provide a "shuttle" customfieldtype.

Available in jira : the soonest is the best......

Cheers,
Pierre-Yves
fields.summary: Change issue component selector / version selector

1.1 beta1

1.1.1
1.1.2
1.1-rc1

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6798].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 4 January 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days; unfortunately we don't have any plans to support this in JIRA for the foreseeable future.

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].
 
I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.
 
Regards,
Dave Meyer
dmeyer@atlassian.com
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

\\

From the JIRA 3.2 Beta Release Notes:
"Continuing our commitment to a fully internationalisable issue manager, JIRA 3.2 provides the ability to translate all issue settings - i.e. Priorities, Statuses, Issue Types, and Resolutions. This allows for even more complete translations to present JIRA to each user in their own chosen language."

I still miss being able to translate the following settings before JIRA is fully internationalisable. 

1. Project Categories
2. Issue linking
3. Sub-Task Types
4. Workflows (i know i can make a new workflow in a second language, but when two persons with two different languages uses the same project, the workflow will only be presented in one of the languages)
5. Custom Fields (same problem as with workflows)
6. Security Levels
7. Field Screen Tabs
8. Field descriptions

In other words: anything unser configurable that is shown to the users.

As long as this is missing, it still gives no sense to use JIRA in a multilanguage environment. My setup is in danish. A person speaking only English will not be able to use it, since the workflow, the security levels, and so on gives no meaning to him.

Disclaimer: I haven't installed 3.2 yet, so if any of the above settings actually IS translatable, please excuse me for not being up-to-date.

Regards,
Lars
fields.summary: Allow admins to translate items configurable in the administration section

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6772].
  {panel}

Currently, if  you want to use a Jira RSS feed in an RSS aggregator, you have to copy the URL and manually add os_username=pol&os_password=pot.
This is a bit of a PITA. Most users dont know this os_incantation.

Also, for the {jiraissues} macro in Confluence, you are forced to put the username/password in clear text.

What I would like to see is something like Fisheye's RSS support. Fisheye generates a url with a security token - which can be used for that URL only. The security tokens are stored against a user - so its possible for a user to nuke all their pre-authenticated tokens.
fields.summary: Generate authenticated token for RSS url

fields.description: At the moment sorting for attachments is by filename and then date. The user should have the choice on what field to sort on.
fields.summary: Allow users to choose sort field for Attachments
Need a way of recreating indexes automatically on startup
Write importer that imports from another JIRA system using XML
Allow for more issue operations and map new operations to screens

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6754].
  {panel}

Sometimes it is hard to contact the correct people in a company regarding the renewal of JIRA maintenance.  Sometimes they have moved position, or left the company, or are otherwise hard to get a hold of.

From within JIRA, we know who the system administrators are.  We should email these people regarding the renewal of their JIRA maintenance, from within JIRA.

We should email them twice - once 3 months out, and then another 1 month out.  We should create a documentation page explaining why they got the email.

This will enable people to be better informed that the maintenance is about to end, and allow people more time to take advantage of any special pricing.

The downside is that we could potentially spam a lot of people.  If the admin list is more than 20 people, we should probably not email anyone (to avoid spamming ppl).

As the email content will ship with JIRA - we must ensure that the copy does not contain any information which may evolve over time (such as licensing or pricing information).  The email should probably inform the user that the maintenance is ending, and point them to an online page.

The option to send reminder emails should be configurable from the administration system (default to on).  We should also record what emails were sent to whom, to prevent any system errors turning into a mail loop.
fields.summary: Email admins about license renewal (from within JIRA)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6753].
  {panel}

Currently, if there is a security advisory, or if there is an upgrade available, there is not a simple way to inform JIRA administrators.

We should design a portlet & admin page that sends details from the local instance to Atlassian, and a page at Atlassian that informs users of the current updates available / pertinent to their system.

This would be done by a simple HMTL 'get' request to the remote Atlassian box, and the Atlassian box can return a small amount of HTML that is then rendered on the client.

As we cannot guarantee the connectivity, the download will need to happen as a service.  We should also set the timeout on the HTTP request to something sensible (like 10-15 seconds).

We need to work out which information to send to Atlassian.  I think initially we should send:
- version number (build number)
- which edition (standard / pro / ent)

I'm not sure if we should send the license details.  On one hand - it would be useful to know when the license ends so that we can send information about which versions are available for upgrade.  On the other hand, it may be a privacy issue (potentially).

Other information which you can send (in the future):
- installed plugins

The information should be displayed as a portlet (available only to admins), and also as a screen in the administration section.

Perhaps for important advisories we should display information as a banner across the top of the administration screen?  If so - we would need a way of indicating that in the response (perhaps we need to use XML instead?).
fields.summary: Create 'remote' portlet / admin screen, which contacts Atlassian for administration information
Create 'vote for issue' system field
Create 'watch issue' system field
Create 'work on issue' system field
Turn system operations into system fields
NNTP plugin should show more descriptive subject for Resolved posts

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6712].
  {panel}

Adding a comment only on the originating issue when linking issues

It might just be me, but I get really cobnfused when I see comments that are created from when people create links. It seems that they appear in both the issue the link is being created from and the target issue. This means that comments that makes sense on the original issue sometimes can be very confusing in the target issue. 

eg. JRA 8326 and JRA-4619

We should be able to at least choose to not add the comment for the target issue. I would be tempted to turn it off really
fields.summary: Adding a comment only on the originating issue when linking issues
Version Control does not find files with lowercase JIRA issue numbers.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6696].
  {panel}

We need to insert a whole table as a custom field. example:

Heading1 | Heading2 | Heading3
---------------------------------------------
Label1      | Value1-1   | Value 1-2
Label2      | Value 2-1  | Value 2-2
..

The only way to create the above table today is by creating 4 separate custom fields. The problem is that our table is a lot larger than the one in the example (15 rows * 6 columns).
fields.summary: Table - new custom field type
Cancelling creation of an issue always sends back to the dashboard

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6682].
  {panel}

Currently, you have two options: 
1) poll cvs
2) manually refresh....

What would be nice would be to provide for a URL-based triggering of the CVS changelog retrieval.
You want a simple url you can simply do a http get (wget) - which can be called by a CVS commit script (ala CVSspam).

For security purposes, you might want to limit the http calls to the server specified in the cvsroot.
It cant require any credentials - otherwise you would have to put them in cleartext in the commit script...

You might also want to expose it via SOAP.
That way we can register a plugin in Fisheye (which is already detecting CVS changes) to call into Jira on cvs commit...

Our CVS server is quite a powerful machine - but it is getting hammerred enough by Cruise Control instances polling - it doesnt need more polling from Jira ;-)
fields.summary: Have a "triggered" mode rather than poll CVS repository.
Ability to hide archived versions in the admin section

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6667].
  {panel}

With enough columns shown in a report, Jira has trouble cramming them into the narrow screen width, especially if the filter editor is open on the left side.

Outlook 2003 added a nice way to deal with this exact same problem. They permitted multi-line (visually) rows in their tables. So I'll have "From", the message type, and when it was received on line 1, then on line two I get the whole subject.

Jira would really benefit from this same behavior. Instead of oddly wrapped or truncated summaries that have to fit in with about ten other fields that are important, they could get an entire line to themselves.

I created a couple mockups in Excel. They're not very pretty but I hope they get the idea across!
fields.summary: Support multi-line tables in web interface queries
Ability to save release notes
On admin page, "Attachments" should be with "Indexing" under "System" settings...
"Jelly Runner" and "Send Email" are under "Options & Settings" Category in Admin?
State change without redirect: secure/admin/MakeDefaultPriority.jspa?make=1
State change without redirect: secure/admin/MakeDefaultResolution.jspa?make=1
State change without redirect: secure/admin/MakeDefaultIssueType.jspa?make=1
Add anchors to the "Manage Versions" page to return to the correct version on the page

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6616].
  {panel}

Need to ensure all HTTP-GET's that cause changes return a redirect - and that the url names are changed.

Redirect means it wont be stored in history.
However, existing installations will already have administrators (perhaps many) who will already have it in their history (or inadvertantly in their bookmarks).
So, for completeness, we should rename these URL's (so anyone who inadvertantly hits a bookmark/history with a pre-fix URL will get a 404)
We have over 100 admins.... its already been possible that they do this accidentally, and it caused us a lot of grief...
fields.summary: Need to ensure all HTTP-GET's that cause changes return a redirect - and that the url names are changed

fields.description: Currently our release note generator assumes a person is invoking the URL, and presents the release notes in a textarea for cut & pasting. This makes it impossible to, for instance, fetch the release notes as part of an automatic build process.
fields.summary: Have distinct URLs for text and HTML release notes
Add Link header for pages with RSS content

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6609].
  {panel}

We would like to be able to have all the release notes of all versions (archived and non-archived) in a single text file.

Is it possible to add an option to /secure/ConfigureReleaseNote.jspa so that we can select 
 "All release notes (archived and non-archived)" and "All release notes (non-archived)". Those options will then need to iterate over all (non)archived releases and display their release notes.

We currently do this manually, because we want to store our release notes in our CVS-server. That makes it very easy to be able to check whether an issue was resolved at the time a release was build. 

Please also make it possible to be able to script it, so that we can integrate in our Ant buildfiles (e.g. use a URL such as:
https://foo.bar/secure/ConfigureReleaseNote.jspa?projectId=ALLRELEASEDVERSIONS).

We would really like this feature, and I don't think it's hard to implement for you guys.

Regards,

Pieter
fields.summary: Display all release notes in text or html
Send notification when user account password is reset

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6601].
  {panel}

Currently we get the NodeAssociations from the database for each issue for every association.  However, it may be useful to get these all in one database call.

We can cache them in a ThreadLocal, so that subsequent hits to the NodeAssociationManager doesn't incur the database hit.  This may also reduce the need for the IssueCache.

From the current entities that we store in that table, it would make sense to cache them all:

insomniac=# select distinct source_node_entity from nodeassociation ;
 source_node_entity
--------------------
 Issue
 Project
(2 rows)
 
insomniac=# select distinct sink_node_entity from nodeassociation ;
   sink_node_entity
-----------------------
 Component
 IssueTypeScreenScheme
 NotificationScheme
 PermissionScheme
 Version
(5 rows)
 
insomniac=# select distinct association_type from nodeassociation ;
 association_type
------------------
 IssueComponent
 IssueFixVersion
 IssueVersion
 ProjectScheme


We should also bound this cache, so that in any thread that hits lots of NodeAssociations, we don't load them all into memory.
fields.summary: Eagerly Cache NodeAssociations

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6595].
  {panel}

Currently, reindexing our server takes a very long time (45mins) - something which I know is being worked on.
But even with this greatly reduced, it still means an outage for Jira - and reindexing during work-hours (if it needs to be done) is quite a problem.

What would be very nice would be to be able to reindex "offline" - ie reindex in such a way that Jira access isnt affected.

Perhaps create a whole new set of indexes in parallel then switch over?
fields.summary: Offline Jira Re-index
Have a project tab panel for version control changes
Highlight invalid search terms from filter in search summary
Allow global/project/user configuration of number of versions in Roadmap

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6528].
  {panel}

A feature that would be very helpful to us would be to have a way to indicate which releases are active, where this would mean that they are currently being worked on. Our workflow is that the team (developers, QA and documentation) are scheduled work to do for a number of forthcoming releases, but most day-to-day activities are meant to be on the current release.

If JIRA supported knowing that a release was 'active' there are a number of useful features that could be implemented:

1. Filters could be implemented to filter out non-active releases (e.g. 'current unresolved issues' would show only unresolved issues assigned to an 'active' release) - see JRA-6527.

2. JIRA could disallow resolving issues to an unreleased and not active release. Often an issue is assigned to a future release but the developer finds that they can fix it early. More often than not the user then resolves the issue as being fixed in this future release, rather than in the upcoming one.

3. When reporting an issue it would be helpful for the 'current' releases to be listed at the top. For a development team, most bugs are found in the release we are currently working on. This is especially true when QAing a candidate release. So it is very annoying that the reporter has to scroll through all of our released versions before getting to the first current release.

I can see that some of these features might need to be configurable as every team has a different workflow. But I think the feature itself would be generally useful.
fields.summary: Support notion of 'active' releases
Document how to create issues via XML-RPC
Issue status per version
Preview of comment/workflow update

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6495].
  {panel}

To further enhance the ability to organaise issues the following could be done:

1. Items (issues) could be bulk-added to containers.
2. Time estimates for items within a container should automatically be aggregated. For example: If the container holds two tasks with 1 day and 2 days remaining, the container's remaining days should be 3.
3. Reports shouldn't double-count the time estimates of container tasks and the tasks that they contain.
4. You should have the option to manipulate contained items along with their containers. For example, if you change the Fix Version for a container task, all of the contained tasks should optionally be moved to that new Fix Version as well.
5. It would be nice if containers could hold other containers, but first-round usefulness wouldn't depend upon this.
6. It would be nice if there were default searches that would automatically display these roadmap views for a given project, but first-round usefulness wouldn't depend upon this. 

Please vote for the issue and andd any comments that you may have.
fields.summary: Organise issues into containers or queues
Appearance of subtasks in a list of issues is confusing
add ability to show index in issue as column in issue navigator

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6467].
  {panel}

Our users do not like the current notification scheme options at the project level.  The 2 requests we had which we could not accommodate include:

- Give permission to turn on/off project notification to a project level user group ( so let our project admins decide if they want to temporarily turn off email notifications for their project since they are going to reorganize issues).

- Create a notification scheme that is triggered off of events and issue level.  Meaning only send emails for issues that are at critical level or above, or only on blocker level.

People are complaining about the frequency of emails and right now we are limited in the different email configuration options we can provide.
fields.summary: Update notification scheme to allow emails to be sent off of issue priority or add ability for notification scheme turn on/off configuration via a permission that can be granted to a project administrators
Add jelly tag to create and configure issue level security schemes
Document custom permissions on JEXT space
"Filter" & "Statistic Type" menus aren't sorted in the Single Level Group By Report

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6436].
  {panel}

When using Jira as a project control tool (not just as a bug base) fix versions for issues may occur frequently. 

It would be really good if a "change fix version" option was available on the left menu when viewing an issue. 

"Change fix version" is readily available in the "bulk change" UI, but it is not in the issue page.

Having to hit the Edit page to change the fix version is counter-productive, and counter security schemes. In fact, changing the fix version should be a priviledge different from being able to edit any part of the issue.
fields.summary: Left menu link for changing fix version
A status report for a selected developer

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-6432].
  {panel}

I'd like to have a OneClick link to create a new bug / task / improvement / feature. 

And I'd like to have it on the dashboard portlet so I can create a new task quickly.

(Aside, I really wish on the standard "Create a new issue" screen that I could have the option of showing a radio-button list of projects in a column on the left...and then buttons on the right for each of the issue types... so for "type" selection, I wouldn't have to click, select a type, click again.... instead, it would be only one click.)

-Tim
P.S. I searched for a while, but didn't find something similar in the 1000's of other open issues/bugs/features :-(
fields.summary: OneClick to create issue from portlet
SubTask Creation Event fired before link is created to Parent
